awd_titl_txt: A Person-Centric Prediction Model of Job Loss based on Social Media
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
It is in the interests of business and public policy to better understand what factors predict job loss beyond a company's financial stress. This research will apply big data mining techniques, and social network and statistical analyses of Twitter data to identify personal factors that predict job loss, over and above a company's business and economic conditions. This topic is important for management and organization science disciplines because most of what we know about job loss is at the society and company level (such as plant closings). The project will lead to a better understanding of how the changing nature of work is affecting people.

The researchers are taking a hybrid big data theory-based approach, using information derived from the popular social media Twitter. Two studies are devised: (1) Identify job loss predictors from micro, meso and macro perspectives in Twitter data by exploiting linguistic and sentiment analysis; (2) Analyze the job topic networks of Twitter users to infer network indices as predictors of job loss. The sets of predictors identified in studies (1) and (2) will be used independently and together as input to a cascade of inference models that will gauge the amount of variance in job loss explained by each of the information domains. This project will extend fundamental methodological knowledge by demonstrating how big data mining might be used in conjunction with statistical analysis to identify multiple predictors of job loss from the content of tweets and social media networks.

por.por_cntn:
Social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook have brought rapid changes to the public communication scenery and are now extensively used by individuals and organizations to promote and discuss content, including employment and health. Social media are an important data resource for research across multiple fields, including research on workers' experiences and health, accompanied by novelty in methodological approaches --machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP). Social media analytics can overcome some of the limitations of traditional methods (e.g., surveys), including difficulties in participant recruitment, low response rates, responder biases, and reliance on the resource- and time-intensive data collection process.

We developed a computational framework for big organic data, specifically data from the Twitter social media platform, analytics tailored to research on workers, with use cases from the job loss and job turnover context. The framework included automated, reproducible data extraction from Twitter, data encoding via NLP guided by extant theory (e.g., inference of personality traits measurements, structuring of micro, meso and macro dimensions), and ML inference.

Such framework enables theory evaluation and development on larger, more complex scales as compared to traditional research paradigms. In addition, it considers dynamic changes both in knowledge base and in real-world evidence. As the most exemplifying use case, we developed a person-centric prediction model of job loss. In detail, our model: (a) integrated predictors from micro, meso and macro perspectives; (b) specified the impact from distal (e.g., personality traits) as well as proximal factors (e.g., job performance); (c) took into consideration dynamics of the individual predictors (e.g., trajectories of psychological states) as well as the interdependence and reciprocal relationships among them, and (d) identified new variables (e.g., online behaviors and social media networks-based indices) that had not been examined in existing research.

Social media and other organic unstructured data can now be used effectively as primary sources for inference studies thanks to the procedural standardization and pipelining that we developed. We also moved forward and started a 'deconstruction' of this procedural standardization to identify possible sources of bias that could impact reproducibility or validity of inference with data distribution shifts. As a result, now it is also possible to identify intrinsic limitations of design and better evaluate underlying, possibly irreducible biases.

Our approaches and models are utilizable beyond research on workers' experiences and health. The computational framework is generally applicable to social media studies on different domains. For instance, we carried out ancillary studies using the same framework applied to cancer awareness, vaccines uptake, and perception of health risks. The methodological development on bias and effects of bias on modelling also impact other disciplines, which provides knowledge on the limitations of study design and outcome evaluation with big organic data.
